AnycostFL: Efficient On-Demand Federated Learning over Heterogeneous Edge Devices

Peichun Li1,2, Guoliang Cheng1, Xumin Huang1,2, Jiawen Kang1, Rong Yu1, Yuan Wu2, and Miao Pan3 1School of Automation, Guangdong University of Technology, Guangzhou, China
2State Key Laboratory of Internet of Things for Smart City, University of Macau, Macau, China
3Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Houston, Houston, USA
Email: peichun@mail2.gdut.edu.cn, guoliang_cheng@126.com, huangxu_min@163.com,
{kavinkang, yurong}@gdut.edu.cn, yuanwu@um.edu.mo, mpan2@uh.edu
Abstract

In this work, we investigate the challenging problem of on-demand federated learning (FL) over heterogeneous edge devices with diverse resource constraints. We propose a cost-adjustable FL framework, named AnycostFL, that enables diverse edge devices to efficiently perform local updates under a wide range of efficiency constraints. To this end, we design the model shrinking to support local model training with elastic computation cost, and the gradient compression to allow parameter transmission with dynamic communication overhead. An enhanced parameter aggregation is conducted in an element-wise manner to improve the model performance. Focusing on AnycostFL, we further propose an optimization design to minimize the global training loss with personalized latency and energy constraints. By revealing the theoretical insights of the convergence analysis, personalized training strategies are deduced for different devices to match their locally available resources. Experiment results indicate that, when compared to the state-of-the-art efficient FL algorithms, our learning framework can reduce up to 1.9 times of the training latency and energy consumption for realizing a reasonable global testing accuracy. Moreover, the results also demonstrate that, our approach significantly improves the converged global accuracy.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, edge intelligence, mobile computing, resource management.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging distributed learning paradigm that enables multiple edge devices to train a common global model without sharing individual data [1]. This privacy-friendly data analytics technique over massive devices is envisioned as a promising solution to realize pervasive intelligence [2]. However, in many real-world application areas, mobile devices are often equipped with different local resources, which raises the emerging challenges for locally on-demand training [3]. Given different local resources status (e.g., computing capability and communication channel state) and personalized efficiency constraints (e.g., latency and energy), it is crucial to customize training strategies for heterogeneous edge devices.

We perform an in-depth analysis on the time delay and the energy consumption for performing the local model updates at edge devices. Specifically, we evaluate and record the cost of local training on three different NVIDIA Jetson family platforms (i.e., Nano, NX AGX, and Xavier AGX) under different channel states (i.e., good, medium, and poor). On the one hand, we observe that the learning efficiency differs significantly with diverse learning scenarios. As shown in Fig. 1, the single-epoch training on Nano with poor communication condition consumes about 4.0 times training latency than that of Xavier AGX with good communication condition, while its energy consumption is about 0.7 times less than the latter one’s. On the other hand, we observe that the bottlenecks of latency and energy are induced by parameter transmission and local model training, respectively.

The above observations provide insights for a proper design of the on-demand FL system. To handle the resource heterogeneity, it is suggested to alleviate the energy and the latency cost of the local device. More importantly, the computation and communication costs should be jointly reduced to achieve efficient local training. In the literature, most existing studies either employ resource allocation and device scheduling to mitigate the system cost [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10], or design gradient compression to accelerate the parameter transmission procedure [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. The former method inherits the ideas of traditional design for mobile edge systems and takes no account of the optimization for neural networks, while the latter overlooks the computation cost of local model training.

In this paper, we propose “anycost” FL, named AnycostFL, to break the latency and energy bottlenecks for on-demand distributed training over heterogeneous edge devices. Our goal is to develop a cost-adjustable FL framework that enables edge devices to perform local updates under diverse learning scenarios. To this end, we first design the model shrinking and gradient compression to enable adaptive local updates with different computation and communication costs. Meanwhile, an enhanced parameter aggregation scheme is proposed to fuse the knowledge of the local updates. Following that, we investigate the on-demand learning of AnycostFL by regulating the local model structure, gradient compression policy and computing frequency under personalized latency and energy constraints. However, customizing training strategy for different learning scenarios is a non-trivial task, since how the global accuracy is affected by the local model structure and compression rate is still unknown. To address this issue, we theoretically reveal the convergence insights of our framework, which are further leveraged to guide optimization analysis. Finally, the optimal training strategy is derived for each device according to its locally available resource.

Our main contributions are summarized as follows.

  • •

    We propose a novel FL framework, named AnycostFL, that enables the local updates with elastic computation cost and communication overhead.

  • •

    We theoretically present the optimal aggregation scheme and convergence analysis for AnycostFL.

  • •

    We investigate the on-demand training problem of AnycostFL, and the optimal training strategy is devised to adapt the locally available resource.

  • •

    Extensive experiments indicate that the proposed AnycostFL outperforms the state-of-the-art efficient FL methods in terms of resource utilization and learning accuracy.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II describes related studies. In Section III, we detail the main operations of AnycostFL to fulfill the single-round training. The problem formulation, theoretical analysis and the corresponding solution are provided in Section IV. The experiment evaluations are presented in Section V, and we finally conclude the paper in Section VI and discuss the future directions.

II Related Work

Resource Management Methods. Resource management methods aim to reduce the FL system cost by arranging the local and system resources. Resource allocation methods employ frequency scheduling [18], transmission power control [19], and bandwidth allocation[20] to balance the cost of local training. Recent device selection methods directly exclude those weak devices with poor computation or communication capabilities to accelerate the convergence time [21, 22, 23]. Besides, topology-aware management is another very effective method to mitigate the network throughput [24, 25, 18]. However, these methods inherit the ideas of the efficient design for traditional mobile systems and overlook the optimization of neural networks.

Neuron-aware Techniques. Neuron-aware techniques focus on revealing the black box of neural networks to improve the training efficiency of the FL system. Early gradient compression utilizes sparsification [11, 26], and quantization[14, 27, 28] to reduce the transmission cost of FL system. In addition, feature maps fusion and knowledge distillation can be carried out to improve the information aggregation [29, 30]. Besides, FedMask proposes to train a personalized mask for each device to improve the test accuracy on the local dataset [31]. Recently, model structure pruning enables multiple devices with different model architectures to train a shared global model [32, 33]. Such methods can reduce the cost of local training, but how to customize optimal training strategies (e.g., gradient compression and model pruning policy) for different learning scenarios is still unknown.

III Training with AnycostFL

In this section, we first outline the overall design of AnycostFL. Next, we detail the key techniques of our framework, including elastic model shrinking (EMS), flexible gradient compression (FGC), and all-in-one aggregation (AIO).

III-A Outline of AnycostFL

We consider a generic application scenario of FL with a set of I𝐼I edge devices ℐ={1,2,⋯,I}ℐ12⋯𝐼{\cal I}=\{1,2,\cdots,I\}. We use 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i} to denote the local training data of the device i𝑖i, and 𝒟=∪i=1I𝒟i𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}={\cup}_{i=1}^{I}{\cal D}_{i} indicates the global data. Let Fi​(𝒘)=ℓ​(𝒘,𝒟i)subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘ℓ𝒘subscript𝒟𝑖F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})=\ell({\boldsymbol{w}},{\cal D}_{i}) represent the local training loss of device i𝑖i with respect to model weight 𝒘𝒘{\boldsymbol{w}}, where ℓ​(⋅,⋅)ℓ⋅⋅\ell(\cdot,\cdot) is the predetermined loss function. The objective of the FL system is to minimize the following global loss function

F​(𝒘)=Δ∑i=1I|𝒟i||𝒟|​Fi​(𝒘),superscriptΔ𝐹𝒘superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝒟𝑖𝒟subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘{F({\boldsymbol{w}})\buildrel\Delta\over{=}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{\frac{{\left|{\cal D}_{i}\right|}}{{\left|{\cal D}\right|}}}{F_{i}}({\boldsymbol{w}})}, (1)

where |𝒟i|subscript𝒟𝑖{\left|{\cal D}_{i}\right|} is the size of 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i}. Given the specified learning task, the original training workload of single sample W𝑊W and the data size of uncompressed gradient S𝑆S can be empirically measured.

As shown in Fig. 2(a), to reduce the computational complexity of the local model training and the communication cost of gradient update transmission, we propose AnycostFL with two device-side techniques, i.e., model shrinking and gradient compression. At the t𝑡t-th global iteration of AnycostFL, the device i𝑖i is enabled to adjust its training workload and gradient size as Wt,i=αt,i​Wsubscript𝑊𝑡𝑖subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖𝑊W_{t,i}=\alpha_{t,i}W and St,i=βt,i​Ssubscript𝑆𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑆S_{t,i}=\beta_{t,i}S, respectively. Here, αt,i∈(0,1]subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖01\alpha_{t,i}\in(0,1] and βt,i∈(0,1]subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖01\beta_{t,i}\in(0,1] are defined as the model shrinking factor and the gradient compression rate, respectively. The training procedure of AnycostFL is summarized as follows.

III-A1 Elastic local training

At the t𝑡t-th global round, the device i𝑖i downloads the latest global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} from the parameter server. With the pre-calculated model shrinking factor αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i}, the specialized sub-model 𝒘t,iα=shrink​(𝒘t,αt,i)superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼shrinksubscript𝒘𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha}=\texttt{shrink}({\boldsymbol{w}}_{t},\alpha_{t,i}) can be efficiently derived, where function shrink​(⋅,⋅)shrink⋅⋅\texttt{shrink}(\cdot,\cdot) indicates the operations for model shrinking. Then, the local training is conducted with sub-model 𝒘t,iαsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha} and local data 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖{\cal D}_{i}, and the updated local sub-model 𝒘t+1,iαsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖𝛼{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1,i}^{\alpha} is obtained. Furthermore, the local gradient update can be acquired as 𝒖t,i=𝒘t,iα−𝒘t+1,iαsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡1𝑖𝛼{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}={\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1,i}^{\alpha}.

III-A2 Flexible gradient upload

To further reduce the uplink traffic, the local device i𝑖i is motivated to compress the gradient update 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} before the parameter transmission. With the given compression rate βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}, the compressed gradient update 𝒖~t,i=cmprs​(𝒖t,i,βt,i)subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖cmprssubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}=\texttt{cmprs}({\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i},\beta_{t,i}) is uploaded to the server, where cmprs​(⋅,⋅)cmprs⋅⋅\texttt{cmprs}(\cdot,\cdot) is the function for gradient compression.

III-A3 Parameter aggregation

The server collects the compressed local updates {𝒖~t,i}∀isubscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} with different shrinking factors {αt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} and compression rates {βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}. After that, the global update is calculated by 𝒖~t=aioagg​({𝒖~t,i}∀i)subscript~𝒖𝑡aioaggsubscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}=\texttt{aioagg}(\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}), where aioagg​(⋅)aioagg⋅\texttt{aioagg}(\cdot) is the server-side all-in-one aggregation. Then, the updated global model is computed as 𝒘t+1=𝒘t−𝒖~tsubscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡subscript~𝒖𝑡{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}={\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}.

After the T𝑇T-round training of the above three-step iterations, the final global model 𝒘Tsubscript𝒘𝑇{\boldsymbol{w}}_{T} is obtained. Before introducing how to customize the values of {αt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} and {βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} in Section IV, we illustrate the details of model shrinking, gradient compression and update aggregation in the rest of this section.

III-B Elastic Model Shrinking

We aim to derive the sub-model 𝒘t,iαsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha} with training complexity of αt,i​Wsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖𝑊\alpha_{t,i}W from global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} by reducing the width of the global model. The shrinking operations work as follows.

III-B1 Server-side channel sorting

To avoid incurring extra memory cost for the edge devices, the server first sorts the channels of the latest global model before the model distribution. Given one layer of the weight of the global model, the server sorts the output channels in the current layer in descending order according to their values of L2 norm, and meanwhile, the input channels of the next layer should be sorted accordingly in the same order to maintain the permutation invariance of the whole model [34].

III-B2 Layer-wise uniform shrinking

Next, the server broadcasts the weight of each layer of the global model in a channel-by-channel manner. Instead of downloading the full global model, each device only receives those important parameters from the global model to assemble the local sub-model. Here, we utilize the fixed shrinking ratio for each layer in the same sub-model. Empirically, given model shrinking factor αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i}, we can reduce the size of the hidden layer by αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\sqrt{\alpha_{t,i}} to acquire the sub-model. For example, as shown in Fig. 2(c), when shrinking a global model with hidden sizes of {16,32,64}163264\{16,32,64\} under αt,i=14subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖14\alpha_{t,i}=\frac{1}{4}, we approximately reduce the size of each hidden layer by half as {8,16,32}81632\{8,16,32\} to form the sub-model.

At the beginning of the t𝑡t-th global round, all device initialize their local sub-models {𝒘t,iα}∀isubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼for-all𝑖{\{{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha}\}}_{\forall i} by choosing the most important channels from the global model 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}. In this way, the training complexity is significantly reduced while maintaining the performance of local sub-models. After that, the local training of device k𝑘k is conducted with sub-model 𝒘t,iαsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝛼{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t,i}^{\alpha}, which produces the local gradient 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} with data size of αt,i​Ssubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖𝑆\alpha_{t,i}S.

III-C Flexible Gradient Compression

Given the local update 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} with the desired compression rate βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}, we aim to obtain the compressed update 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} with data size of αt,i​βt,i​Ssubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑆\alpha_{t,i}\beta_{t,i}S. Let ρt,isubscript𝜌𝑡𝑖\rho_{t,i} and Lt,isubscript𝐿𝑡𝑖L_{t,i} denote the sparsity rate and the number of quantization levels, respectively. The gradient compression scheme works as follows.

III-C1 Kernel-wise sparsification

Without loss of generality, we take the convolution neural network (CNN) as an example to illustrate the sparsification procedure. We aim to acquire the sparse update 𝒖^t,isubscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} from 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}. Let 𝒖t,i​[k]subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑘{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}[k] denote the k𝑘k-th kernel of 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}, and 𝒖t,i={𝒖t,i​[k]}∀ksubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖subscriptsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑘for-all𝑘{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}=\{{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}[k]\}_{\forall k}. We measure the importance of each kernel and obtain 𝒩={‖𝒖t,i​[k]‖2}∀k𝒩subscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑘2for-all𝑘{\cal N}=\{\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}[k]\|_{2}\}_{\forall k}, where ∥⋅∥2\|\cdot\|_{2} denotes the L2 norm operation. Next, by selecting the ⌈ρt,i​K⌉subscript𝜌𝑡𝑖𝐾\lceil\rho_{t,i}K\rceil-th largest value in 𝒩𝒩\cal N as the threshold ΠΠ\Pi, the kernel-wise sparsification is expressed as

𝒖^t,i​[k]={𝟎if ‖𝒖t,i​[k]‖2<Π,𝒖t,i​[k]otherwise.subscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑘cases0if ‖𝒖t,i[k]‖2<Π,subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑘otherwise.\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}[k]=\begin{cases}\bf{0}&\text{if $\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}[k]\|_{2}<\Pi$,}\\ {\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}[k]&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases} (2)

Meanwhile, the binary mask of 𝒖^t,isubscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} is denoted as 𝒎t,isubscript𝒎𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i}.

III-C2 Probabilistic quantization

Motivated by the studies in [35, 36], we aim to obtain the quantized update 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} with the given sparse 𝒖^t,isubscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} and the quantization level Lt,isubscript𝐿𝑡𝑖L_{t,i}. Let u∈𝒖^t,i𝑢subscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖u\in\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} be a scalar value. To begin with, we first calculate the magnitude range of the non-zero elements of 𝒖^t,isubscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}, denoted as [umin,umax]subscript𝑢subscript𝑢[u_{\min},u_{\max}], where umin=min{|u|}∀u≠0u_{\min}=\min\{|u|\}_{\forall u\neq 0}, and umax=max{|u|}∀u≠0u_{\max}=\max\{|u|\}_{\forall u\neq 0}. Next, let 𝒬={Ql}l=1Lt,i𝒬superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄𝑙𝑙1subscript𝐿𝑡𝑖{\cal Q}=\{Q_{l}\}_{l=1}^{L_{t,i}} denote the set of quantization points, where Qlsubscript𝑄𝑙Q_{l} is computed by

Ql=l​(umax−umin)Lt,i+umin.subscript𝑄𝑙𝑙subscript𝑢subscript𝑢subscript𝐿𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢{Q_{l}}=\frac{{l\left({u_{\max}-{u_{\min}}}\right)}}{L_{t,i}}+{u_{\min}}. (3)

For any u∈𝒖^t,i𝑢subscript^𝒖𝑡𝑖u\in\hat{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} and u≠0𝑢0u\neq 0, we can always find a quantization interval [Ql,Ql+1]subscript𝑄𝑙subscript𝑄𝑙1[Q_{l},Q_{l+1}] such that Ql≤|u|≤Ql+1subscript𝑄𝑙𝑢subscript𝑄𝑙1Q_{l}\leq|u|\leq Q_{l+1}, and its corresponding quantized value u~~𝑢\tilde{u} is further computed by

u~={sgn​(u)⋅Qlwith probability Ql+1−|u|Ql+1−Ql,sgn​(u)⋅Ql+1otherwise,~𝑢cases⋅sgn𝑢subscript𝑄𝑙with probability Ql+1−|u|Ql+1−Ql,⋅sgn𝑢subscript𝑄𝑙1otherwise,\tilde{u}=\begin{cases}\texttt{sgn}(u)\cdot Q_{l}&\text{with probability $\frac{{{Q_{l+1}}-|u|}}{{{Q_{l+1}}-{Q_{l}}}}$,}\\ \texttt{sgn}(u)\cdot Q_{l+1}&\text{otherwise,}\\ \end{cases} (4)

where sgn​(⋅)sgn⋅\texttt{sgn}(\cdot) calculates the sign of the given scalar. Furthermore, the set of the quantization indices of all u~∈𝒖~t,i~𝑢subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{u}\in\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} is denoted as ℒt,i={l,Ql=u~}∀u~≠0subscriptℒ𝑡𝑖subscript𝑙subscript𝑄𝑙~𝑢for-all~𝑢0{\cal L}_{t,i}=\{l,Q_{l}=\tilde{u}\}_{\forall\tilde{u}\neq 0}. Now, 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} can be represented by a tuple of {umin,umax,Lt,i,𝒎t,i,ℒt,i}subscript𝑢subscript𝑢subscript𝐿𝑡𝑖subscript𝒎𝑡𝑖subscriptℒ𝑡𝑖\{u_{\min},u_{\max},L_{t,i},{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i},{\cal L}_{t,i}\}.

III-C3 Lossless encoding

Due to the distribution characteristics of Lt,isubscript𝐿𝑡𝑖L_{t,i} that smaller indices may occur more frequently, we apply entropy coding to reduce the data size [37, 14]. Besides, the sparse binary matrix 𝒎t,isubscript𝒎𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i} can be compressed by Golomb encoding [11, 38].

After determining the compression scheme, we can vary the combinations of {ρt,i,Lt,i}subscript𝜌𝑡𝑖subscript𝐿𝑡𝑖\{\rho_{t,i},L_{t,i}\} and record the corresponding compression rates. Based on the results, we can build a piecewise linear function to predict the compression strategy {ρt,i,Lt,i}subscript𝜌𝑡𝑖subscript𝐿𝑡𝑖\{\rho_{t,i},L_{t,i}\} with the given βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}. Notably, this function can be efficiently fitted by the server with a rather small amount of public training data (e.g., 16 samples) in an offline manner.

III-D All-in-One Aggregation

After all the devices upload their encoded updates, the server receives, decodes and then reconstructs the compressed local updates {𝒖~t,i}∀isubscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}. Our goal is to obtain the global update 𝒖~tsubscript~𝒖𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t} by aggregating {𝒖~t,i}∀isubscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}. However, the aggregation of local updates in our framework cannot be supported by conventional FedAvg [1], since the local updates are produced by different model structures with different levels of precision (i.e., different quantization levels and sparsity).

To tackle the above challenge, we propose an all-in-one aggregation scheme that fuses the local updates in an element-wise manner. Let the set {1,2,⋯,J}12⋯𝐽\{1,2,\cdots,J\} index elements of the global update 𝒖~tsubscript~𝒖𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}, and 𝒖~t[j]superscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡delimited-[]𝑗\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}^{[j]} denote the j𝑗j-th element of 𝒖~tsubscript~𝒖𝑡\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}. To accomplish the aggregation for 𝒖~t[j]superscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡delimited-[]𝑗\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}^{[j]}, we first determine the subset of devices ℐj⊆ℐsubscriptℐ𝑗ℐ{\cal I}_{j}\subseteq{\cal I} whose local model structure also contains the j𝑗j-th element. Then, we have

𝒖~t[j]={0if ∑i∈ℐj𝒎t,i[j]=0,1∑i∈ℐjpt,i​𝒎t,i[j]​∑i∈ℐjpt,i​𝒎t,i[j]​𝒖t,i[j]otherwise,superscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡delimited-[]𝑗cases0if ∑i∈ℐj𝒎t,i[j]=0,1subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝑗subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑗subscript𝑖subscriptℐ𝑗subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖delimited-[]𝑗otherwise,\small\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}^{[j]}=\begin{cases}0&\text{if ${\sum\limits_{i\in{\cal I}_{j}}{{{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i}^{[j]}}}}=0$,}\\ \frac{1}{{\sum\limits_{i\in{\cal I}_{j}}{{p_{t,i}}{{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i}^{[j]}}}}}\sum\limits_{i\in{\cal I}_{j}}{{p_{t,i}}{{\boldsymbol{m}}_{t,i}^{[j]}}{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}^{[j]}}&\text{otherwise,}\\ \end{cases} (5)

where pt,isubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖p_{t,i} is the aggregation coefficient for the j𝑗j-th device at the t𝑡t-th global round. The optimal values of {pt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{p_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} will be further analyzed in Section IV. Fig. 3 gives an example to illustrate the aggregation details. Specifically, different elements in the global update are updated by different subsets of devices, and more important elements will “absorb” knowledge from more devices. When the j𝑗j-th element is zeroed out by all the devices in ℐjsubscriptℐ𝑗{\cal I}_{j}, we have 𝒖~t[j]=0superscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡delimited-[]𝑗0\tilde{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}^{[j]}=0.

IV Theoretical Analysis and Optimization

In this section, we focus on the optimization of our framework by customizing the training strategies for diverse devices. We first formulate the on-demand training problem of AnycostFL. Then, we derive the upper bound of the convergence rate and reveal the key insights to improve the performance of AnycostFL. Based on the analysis, the optimization problem is transformed into a tractable form, and the closed-form solution is derived.

IV-A AnycostFL over Wireless Networks

In this subsection, we formulate the computation and communication models for our framework. After that, we build up an on-demand learning problem that minimizes the global training loss with given delay and energy constraints.

IV-A1 Computation model

For the device i𝑖i at the t𝑡t-th global round, given the model shrinking factor αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i} and computing frequency ft,isubscript𝑓𝑡𝑖f_{t,i}, the time consumption of local model training can be measured by

Tt,icmp=τ​|𝒟i|​αt,i​Wft,i,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖cmp𝜏subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖𝑊subscript𝑓𝑡𝑖T_{t,i}^{\text{cmp}}=\frac{{\tau|{\cal D}_{i}|\alpha_{t,i}W}}{f_{t,i}}, (6)

where τ𝜏\tau denotes the number of local epochs. Meanwhile, the corresponding energy consumption can be given by

Et,icmp=ϵi​ft,i2​τ​|𝒟i|​αt,i​W,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖cmpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑖2𝜏subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖𝑊E_{t,i}^{\text{cmp}}=\epsilon_{i}f_{t,i}^{2}{\tau|{\cal D}_{i}|\alpha_{t,i}W}, (7)

where ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} is the hardware energy coefficient of the device i𝑖i.

IV-A2 Communication model

We consider the frequency division multiple access (FDMA) scheme for the transmission of the local gradient update. For the device i𝑖i at the t𝑡t-th global round, the achievable transmitting rate can be estimated by

rt,i=bi​log2⁡(1+|ht,i|​Pt,icomN0​bi),subscript𝑟𝑡𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖subscript21subscriptℎ𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑖comsubscript𝑁0subscript𝑏𝑖r_{t,i}={b_{i}}{\log_{2}}\Big{(}1+\frac{{|h_{t,i}|P_{t,i}^{\text{com}}}}{{{N_{0}}{b_{i}}}}\Big{)}, (8)

where Pt,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑖comP_{t,i}^{\text{com}} is the transmitting power; bisubscript𝑏𝑖b_{i} is the achievable bandwidth; |ht,i|subscriptℎ𝑡𝑖|h_{t,i}| denotes the path loss of wireless channel; N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is the power spectral density of the additive white Gaussian noise. For the device i𝑖i at t𝑡t-th global round, given the update 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} generated by the local model with a shrinking factor of αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i} and compression rate of βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}, the required time Tt,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖comT_{t,i}^{\text{com}} and energy consumption Et,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖comE_{t,i}^{\text{com}} of uplink transmission can be respectively measured by

Tt,icom=αt,i​βt,i​Srt,i,and ​Et,icom=Tt,icom​Pt,icom.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖comsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑆subscript𝑟𝑡𝑖and superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖comsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖comsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑖com\small T_{t,i}^{\text{com}}=\frac{{{\alpha_{t,i}}{\beta_{t,i}}S}}{{{r_{t,i}}}},~{}\text{and }E_{t,i}^{\text{com}}=T_{t,i}^{\text{com}}P_{t,i}^{\text{com}}. (9)

With the above computation and communication models, we next focus on the optimization problem of AnycostFL.

IV-A3 Problem formulation

To optimize AnycostFL, we study an on-demand training problem. Specifically, the shared maximal latency for each round Tmaxsuperscript𝑇T^{\max} is determined by the server. The local energy consumption budget for each round Et,imaxsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖E_{t,i}^{\max} is customized by the device itself. Given multiple devices with diverse local resources (e.g., computation, communication and data), our goal is to customize the training strategy for each device to minimize the global training loss with personalized constraints (e.g., latency and energy). To sum up, at the t𝑡t-th global round, we aim to optimize the following problem.

(P1)P1\displaystyle({\text{P1}}) minF(𝒘t;{α\displaystyle\min F\big{(}{{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}};\{\alpha }∀it,i,{βt,i}∀i){}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i},\{\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}\big{)} (10)
subject to: Tt,icmp+Tt,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑡𝑖com\displaystyle T_{t,i}^{\text{cmp}}+T_{t,i}^{\text{com}} ≤Tmax,∀i,absentsuperscript𝑇for-all𝑖\displaystyle\leq{T^{\max}},\forall i, (10a)
Et,icmp+Et,icomsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖cmpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖com\displaystyle E_{t,i}^{\text{cmp}}+E_{t,i}^{\text{com}} ≤Et,imax,∀i,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\displaystyle\leq{E_{t,i}^{\max}},\forall i, (10b)
αmin≤αt,isuperscript𝛼subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\displaystyle{\alpha^{\min}}\leq{\alpha_{t,i}} ≤1,∀i,absent1for-all𝑖\displaystyle\leq 1,\forall i, (10c)
0≤βt,i0subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\displaystyle 0\leq{\beta_{t,i}} ≤βmax,∀i,absentsuperscript𝛽for-all𝑖\displaystyle\leq\beta^{\max},\forall i, (10d)
fimin≤ft,isuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑓𝑡𝑖\displaystyle f_{i}^{\min}\leq f_{t,i} ≤fimax,∀i,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖for-all𝑖\displaystyle\leq f_{i}^{\max},\forall i, (10e)
variables: {αt,i,β\displaystyle\{\alpha_{t,i},\beta ,t,ift,i}∀i,{}_{t,i},f_{t,i}\}_{\forall i},

where F​(𝒘t;{αt,i}∀i,{βt,i}∀i)𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖subscriptsubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖F\big{(}{{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}};\{\alpha_{t,i}\}_{\forall i},\{\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}\big{)} denotes the global loss of the t𝑡t-th round with given the global model weight 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} under the training strategies of {αt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} and {βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}. In the rest of this section, we analyze the relationship between training loss and training strategies. After that, Problem (P1) is further solved based on the theoretical insights.

IV-B Assumptions and Key Lemmas

Being in line with the studies in [5, 39], we make the following assumptions for the local loss function Fi,∀isubscript𝐹𝑖for-all𝑖F_{i},\forall i.

Assumption 1.

Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is λ𝜆\lambda-Lipschitz: ‖Fi​(𝒘)−Fi​(𝒘′)‖≤λ​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖normsubscript𝐹𝑖𝒘subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′𝜆norm𝒘superscript𝒘′\left\|{F_{i}}({\boldsymbol{w}})-{F_{i}}({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime})\right\|\leq\lambda\left\|{\boldsymbol{w}}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime}\right\|, where λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0.

Assumption 2.

Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is ν𝜈\nu-strongly convex: Fi​(𝒘)≥Fi​(𝒘′)+(𝒘−𝒘′)⊤​∇Fi​(𝒘′)+ν2​‖𝒘−𝒘′‖2subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′superscript𝒘superscript𝒘′top∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘′𝜈2superscriptnorm𝒘superscript𝒘′2F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})\geq F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime})+({\boldsymbol{w}}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime})^{\top}\nabla{F_{i}}({\boldsymbol{w}^{\prime}})+\frac{\nu}{2}\left\|{\boldsymbol{w}}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}.

Assumption 3.

Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is twice-continuously differentiable. Based on Assumptions 1 and 2, we have ν​𝐈⪯∇2Fi​(𝒘)⪯λ​𝐈precedes-or-equals𝜈𝐈superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘precedes-or-equals𝜆𝐈\nu{\bf I}\preceq\nabla^{2}F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})\preceq\lambda{\bf I}.

Assumption 4.

The ratios between the norms of ∇Fi​(𝒘)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}}) and ∇F​(𝒘)∇𝐹𝒘\nabla F({\boldsymbol{w}}) are bounded: ‖∇Fi​(𝒘)‖2≤ε​‖∇F​(𝒘)‖2superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘2𝜀superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝒘2\left\|\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})\right\|^{2}\leq\varepsilon\left\|\nabla F({\boldsymbol{w}})\right\|^{2}, where ε≥0𝜀0\varepsilon\geq 0 is a positive constant.

Assumption 5.

For the moderate shrinking factor α≥αmin𝛼superscript𝛼\alpha\geq\alpha^{\min}, the first-shrinking-then-training can be approximated as first-training-then-shrinking: ∇Fi​(𝒘α)=[∇Fi​(𝒘)]α∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝒘𝛼superscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝛼\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\alpha})=[\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})]^{\alpha}. Here, we use [∇Fi​(𝒘)]αsuperscriptdelimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘𝛼[\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}})]^{\alpha} to denote the shrinking operation for ∇Fi​(𝒘)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝒘\nabla F_{i}({\boldsymbol{w}}).

Next, we give the following two definitions.

Definition 1 (Local gradient divergence).

The local gradient divergence δt,isubscript𝛿𝑡𝑖\delta_{t,i} is defined as the difference between 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} and 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}, which is given by δt,i=‖𝒖t,i−𝒖~t,i‖subscript𝛿𝑡𝑖normsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\delta_{t,i}=\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}-\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\|.

Definition 2 (Global gradient divergence).

The global gradient divergence ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t} is defined as the difference between 𝒖tsubscript𝒖𝑡{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t} and 𝒖~tsubscript~𝒖𝑡\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}, which is measured by Δt=‖𝒖t−𝒖~t‖=‖∑i=1Ipt,i​𝒖t,i−∑i=1Ipt,i​𝒖~t,i‖subscriptΔ𝑡normsubscript𝒖𝑡subscript~𝒖𝑡normsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\Delta_{t}=\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}-\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}\|={\Big{\|}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}}{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}}-{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}}\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}}\Big{\|}}.

Notably, in Definition 1, 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} and 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} may have different dimensions. We pad the missing elements in 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} with zeros before the arithmetic operation. Next, we are interested in how the training strategies {αt,i,βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i},\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} affect {δt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛿𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\delta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} and ΔtsubscriptΔ𝑡\Delta_{t}. We derive the following two lemmas.

Lemma 1.

For the local training with the model shrinking factor αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i} and compression rate βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}. The square of the local gradient divergence is bounded by

𝔼​‖δt,i‖2≤(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2​𝔼​‖𝒖t,i‖2.𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝛿𝑡𝑖2superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖2{\mathbb{E}}\|\delta_{t,i}\|^{2}\leq\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}{\mathbb{E}}\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}\|^{2}. (11)
  • Proof.

    See Appendix A. ∎

Lemma 2.

For the local update {𝒖~t,i,∀i}subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i},\forall i\} with the corresponding training strategies {αt,i,βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i},\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} and aggregation coefficients {pt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{p_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}, the square of the global gradient divergence is bounded by

𝔼​‖Δt‖2≤I​ε​η2​∑i=1Ipt,i2​(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2​𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝑡2𝐼𝜀superscript𝜂2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖2superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}{\left\|\Delta_{t}\right\|^{2}}\leq I\varepsilon\eta^{2}{{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{p_{t,i}^{2}}\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}}}{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}.\end{split} (12)
  • Proof.

    See Appendix B. ∎

IV-C Optimal Aggregation Scheme and Convergence Analysis

Intuitively, the local update 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i} generated with larger {αt,i,βt,i}subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i},\beta_{t,i}\} may carry more accurate information, and thus a larger pt,isubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖p_{t,i} should be assigned during the aggregation. Based on Lemma 2, we deduce the following theorem.

Theorem 1 (Optimal aggregation scheme).

Given the local updates {𝒖~t,i}∀isubscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}\}_{\forall i} with corresponding training strategies {αt,i,βt,i}∀isubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\{\alpha_{t,i},\beta_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}, the optimal aggregation coefficients are

pt,i∗=1(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2∑i1(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2,∀i.superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖∗1superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2subscript𝑖1superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2for-all𝑖\displaystyle\begin{split}p_{t,i}^{\ast}=\frac{{\frac{1}{{{{\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}}^{2}}}}}}{{\sum\nolimits_{i}{\frac{1}{{{{\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}}^{2}}}}}}},\forall i.\end{split} (13)
  • Proof.

    Based on Lemma 2, we study the following optimization problem to minimize the global gradient divergence.

    (P2)P2\displaystyle({\text{P2}}) min{pt,i}∀i∑i=1Ipt,i2(1−α\displaystyle\mathop{\min}\limits_{\{p_{t,i}\}_{\forall i}}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{p_{t,i}^{2}}\big{(}1-\alpha (2−αt,i)t,iβt,i)2{}_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2} (14)
    subject to: pt,i≥subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖absent\displaystyle p_{t,i}\geq 0,∀i,0for-all𝑖\displaystyle 0,\forall i, (14a)
    ∑i=1Isuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I} pt,i=1.subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖1\displaystyle{{p_{t,i}}}=1. (14b)

    It can be verified that Problem (P2) is a convex optimization problem. We further solve the problem by the Karush–Kuhn–Tucker (KKT) conditions. Let {ϖ}∀isubscriptitalic-ϖfor-all𝑖\{\varpi\}_{\forall i} and θ𝜃\theta be the Lagrange multipliers for Constraints (14a) and (14b), respectively. Then, we obtain

    ϖi≥0,ϖi​pt,i=0,pt,i≥0,∑i=1Ipt,i=1,2​pt,i​(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2−ϖi+θ=0,∀i.formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϖ𝑖0formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϖ𝑖subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖0formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖12subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2subscriptitalic-ϖ𝑖𝜃0for-all𝑖\displaystyle\small\begin{split}\varpi_{i}\geq 0,\;\;\varpi_{i}p_{t,i}=0,\;\;p_{t,i}\geq 0,\;\;\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}}=1,\\ 2{p_{t,i}}\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}-\varpi_{i}+\theta=0,\;\forall i.\end{split} (15)

    Being in line with the study in [40], we can obtain

    pt,i=−θ2​(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2.subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖𝜃2superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2p_{t,i}=-\frac{\theta}{2\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}}. (16)

    By putting Eqn. (16) into Eqn. (14b), we obtain

    θ=−2∑k1(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2.𝜃2subscript𝑘1superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2\theta=-\frac{2}{\sum\nolimits_{k}{\frac{1}{\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}}}}. (17)

    Putting Eqn. (17) into Eqn. (16) completes the proof. ∎

With the optimal aggregation scheme, we investigate the upper bound of the convergence rate of AnycostFL.

Definition 3 (Local and global learning gains).

The local and global learning gains are defined as gt,i=αt,i4​βt,isubscript𝑔𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖4subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖g_{t,i}=\alpha_{t,i}^{4}\beta_{t,i} and gt=∑igt,i/Isubscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝑔𝑡𝑖𝐼g_{t}={\sum\nolimits_{i}{g_{t,i}}}/I, respectively. Specifically, the local and global learning gains (i.e., gt,i∈[0,1]subscript𝑔𝑡𝑖01g_{t,i}\in[0,1] and gt∈[0,1]subscript𝑔𝑡01g_{t}\in[0,1]) measure the amount of effective information carried in the local and global updates, respectively.

Theorem 2 (Convergence rate of AnycostFL).

Let gmin=min{gt}∀tg^{\min}=\min\{g_{t}\}_{\forall t} be the minimal global learning gain over the T𝑇T-round training. The upper bound of the convergence rate of AnycostFL satisfies

𝔼​(F​(𝒘T)−F​(𝒘∗))≤ZT−1​𝔼​(F​(𝒘0)−F​(𝒘∗)),𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘∗superscript𝑍𝑇1𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘∗\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{T}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)}&\leq Z^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{0}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)},\end{split} (18)

where Z=1−νλ​(1−ε​(1−gmin))𝑍1𝜈𝜆1𝜀1superscript𝑔Z=1-\frac{\nu}{\lambda}\left({1-{\varepsilon}({1-g^{\min}})}\right). Recall that parameters ν,λ𝜈𝜆\nu,\lambda and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon are defined in Assumptions 1 to 4 before.

  • Proof.

    See Appendix C. ∎

Based on Definition 3 and Theorem 2, we derive the following proposition.

Proposition 1.

The key to minimizing the training loss of AnycostFL is to maximize the learning gain gtsubscript𝑔𝑡g_{t} for each global round. If gt=1​∀tsubscript𝑔𝑡1for-all𝑡g_{t}=1~{}\forall t, AnycostFL degrades to conventional FL without model shrinking and gradient compression.

IV-D Solution for Problem (P1)

Based on Theorem 2 and Proposition 1, Problem (P1) can be transformed into the following problem.

Based on Lemma 3, we employ two intermediate variables (i.e., ϕt,isubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡𝑖\phi_{t,i} and φt,isubscript𝜑𝑡𝑖\varphi_{t,i}) for each device to reparameterize Problem (P3). Notably, the decision-making process of each device does not involve the auxiliary information of the resource status from other devices. At the beginning of each global round, each device can determine its training strategy locally.

V Experiment Evaluations

V-A Experiment Settings

V-A1 Setup for FL training

We consider the FL application with image classification on Fashion-MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets [41, 42]. For Fashion-MNIST, we use a small convolutional neural network (CNN) with data size of model update as 53.22Mb [1]. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we employ VGG-9 with data size of model update as 111.7Mb [43]. For IID and non-IID data settings, we follow the dataset partition strategy in [34]. For the learning hyper-parameters, the learning rate, batch size and local epoch are set as {0.01, 32, 1} for Fashion-MNIST and {0.08, 64, 1} for CIFAR-10 dataset. The maximal latency is set as Tmax=10superscript𝑇10T^{\max}=10 seconds and the energy budget is set as Et,imax∼U​[3,9]similar-tosubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑡𝑖𝑈39E^{\max}_{t,i}\sim U[3,9] joules for the CIFAR-10 dataset, and the corresponding hyper-parameters for the FMNIST dataset are halved by default. Additionally, we set αmin=1/4superscript𝛼14\alpha^{\min}=1/4 and βmax=1/15superscript𝛽115\beta^{\max}=1/15.

V-A2 Setup for mobile system

We investigate a mobile system with I=60𝐼60I=60 devices located within a circle cell with a radius of 550 meters, and a base station is situated at the center. To simulate the mobility, the position of each device is refreshed randomly at the beginning of each round [44]. For the computation, the energy coefficient is set as ϵi∼U[5×10−27,1×1−26\epsilon_{i}\sim U[5\times 10^{-27},1\times 1^{-26}]. For communication, the bandwidth is set as 111MHz equally for each device, and the path loss exponent is 3.76. The transmission power is set as 0.10.10.1W, and N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is set as −114114-114dBm/MHz.

V-B Performance Comparisons

We compare the proposed AnycostFL with the following efficient FL algorithms with three different random seeds.

  • •

    STC. The sparse ternary compression (STC) is adapted to reduce the cost of uplink parameter transmission [11].

  • •

    QSGD. The TopK sparsification and probabilistic quantization are combined to compress the local gradient [36].

  • •

    UVeQFed. The TopK sparsification and universal vector quantization are used to compress the local gradient [14].

  • •

    HeteroFL. Each device trains the local sub-model in different widths to match its computation capacity [32].

  • •

    FedHQ. Each device uses different quantization levels to compress the gradient according to its channel state [40].

Fig. 4 shows the performance of the global model over time consumption and energy consumption under the IID and the non-IID data setting. With the same training efficiency (i.e., time and energy consumption), the proposed AnycostFL consistently outperforms the baseline schemes to improve the test accuracy of the global model. Meanwhile, Table I provides the best accuracy and required system cost for achieving the specified test accuracy. Particularly, when compared with HeterFL and FedHQ, AnycostFL can reduce up to 1.9 times the energy consumption to reach the test accuracy of 82% on CIFAR-10 dataset under the IID setting. When compared with STC, AnycostFL can reduce up to 1.7 times the time consumption to reach the test accuracy of 90% on FMNIST dataset under the IID setting. Moreover, our framework can significantly improve the best accuracy of the global model by 2.33% and 1.82% on CIFAR-10 dataset under the IID and the non-IID settings, respectively.

V-C Impact of Key Mechanisms and Hyper-parameters

Fig. 5(a) verifies the advantages of the main techniques of AnycostFL. We gradually remove the elastic model shrinking (w/o EMS), the flexible gradient compression (w/o FGC) and the all-in-one aggregation (w/o AIO), and record the required system cost to achieve 80% test accuracy with CIFAR-10 dataset under the IID setting. We observe that the proposed EMS and FGC can significantly save the energy consumption and training time, respectively. Besides, AIO contributes to saving both energy and time.

We next evaluate the impact of resource heterogeneity on the training efficiency in Fig. 5(b-c). We set the average energy coefficient ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} as 7.5×10−277.5superscript10277.5\times 10^{-27} and the average distance between the base station and edge devices as 400 meters, and then change their variances to simulate the computation and communication heterogeneity, respectively. The larger variance indicates a higher level of system heterogeneity. As we expect, the proposed AnycostFL shows more resilience than other baselines to tackle the high level of system heterogeneity.

We also evaluate the performance of sub-models in different widths in Fig. 5(d). Specifically, We compare AnycostFL with HeteroFL (i.e., local training with different widths) and STC (i.e., the best-performing compression-only method). The sub-models are derived from the well-trained global model without further re-training. Surprisingly, the sub-models of the global model trained by AnycostFL can still maintain satisfactory test accuracy, which provides dynamic inference for diverse edge devices after the training time.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed AnycostFL, a joint computation and communication efficient framework for FL, that enables edge devices with diverse resources to train a shared global model. We aimed to minimize the global training loss under given personalized latency and energy constraints. By leveraging the theoretical insight of AnycostFL, we decomposed the optimization problem into multiple sub-problems. Following that, the optimal training strategy is derived for each device according to its locally available resource. Experiments demonstrate the advantage of our framework in improving the system efficiency and model performance compared to the state-of-the-art methods.

Appendix A Proof of Lemma 1

  • Proof.

    For the given local gradient 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} with shrinking factor αt,isubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖\alpha_{t,i} and gradient compression rate βt,isubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\beta_{t,i}, we aim to capture the divergence between 𝒖~t,isubscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} and 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}.     For clear notation, we sort the element-wise absolute value of 𝒖t,isubscript𝒖𝑡𝑖{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i} in ascending order. Proof.

Based on Definition 2 and Lemma 11, we have

𝔼​‖Δt‖2=𝔼​‖∑i=1Ipt,i​𝒖t,i−∑i=1Ipt,i​𝒖~t,i‖2≤𝔼​(∑i=1Ipt,i​(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)​‖𝒖t,i‖)2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝑡2𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript~𝒖𝑡𝑖2𝔼superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖delimited-∥∥subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}{\left\|\Delta_{t}\right\|^{2}}&={\mathbb{E}}{\Big{\|}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}}{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}}-{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}}\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t,i}}\Big{\|}^{2}}\\ &\leq{\mathbb{E}}{\Big{(}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{{p_{t,i}}\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}\left\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}\right\|}}\Big{)}^{2}}.\end{split} (33)

We use η𝜂\eta to denote the learning rate, and 𝒖t,i=η​∇Fi​(𝒘t)subscript𝒖𝑡𝑖𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝒘𝑡{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t,i}=\eta\nabla F_{i}({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}}). Based on Assumption 4, we obtain

Appendix C On the Convergence of AnycostFL

Proof.

Inspired by the studies in [5, 39], we deduce the convergence analysis of AnycostFL. According to Taylor expansion and Assumption 3, we have

F​(𝒘t+1)≤F​(𝒘t)+(𝒘t+1−𝒘t)⊤​∇F​(𝒘t)+λ2​‖𝒘t+1−𝒘t‖2=F​(𝒘t)−𝒖~t⊤​∇F​(𝒘t)+λ2​‖𝒖~t‖2.𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡1𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡top∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡2𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝒖𝑡top∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript~𝒖𝑡2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}})&\leq F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})+{({\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t})^{\top}}\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\left\|{{{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}}-{{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}}}\right\|^{2}}\\ &=F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-{{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}}^{\top}}\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\big{\|}{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{u}}}_{t}}\big{\|}^{2}}.\end{split} (36)

By using learning rate η=1λ𝜂1𝜆\eta=\frac{1}{\lambda}, we obtain

𝔼​(F​(𝒘t+1))≤𝔼​(F​(𝒘t)−λ​(𝒖t−Δt)⊤​𝒖t+λ2​‖𝒖t−Δt‖2)=𝔼​(F​(𝒘t)−12​λ​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2+λ2​‖Δt‖2).𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡1𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡𝜆superscriptsubscript𝒖𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡topsubscript𝒖𝑡𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝒖𝑡subscriptΔ𝑡2𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡12𝜆superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡2𝜆2superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝑡2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}})\big{)}&\leq{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-{\lambda\left({\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}-\Delta_{t}\right)^{\top}}{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\|{\boldsymbol{u}}_{t}-\Delta_{t}\|^{2}}\Big{)}\\ &={\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-\frac{1}{2\lambda}{\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}}+\frac{\lambda}{2}{\|\Delta_{t}\|^{2}}\Big{)}.\end{split} (37)

We now pay attention to the upper bound of ‖Δt‖2superscriptnormsubscriptΔ𝑡2{\left\|\Delta_{t}\right\|^{2}}. Based on Jensen’s inequality and Eqn. (34), we obtain

𝔼​‖Δt‖2≤ε​η2​∑i=1Ipt,i​(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2⏟(D)​𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2.𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝑡2𝜀superscript𝜂2subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑝𝑡𝑖superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2D𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}{\left\|\Delta_{t}\right\|^{2}}&\leq\varepsilon\eta^{2}{\underbrace{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{p_{t,i}}\big{(}1-\alpha_{t,i}(2-\alpha_{t,i})\sqrt{\beta_{t,i}}\big{)}^{2}}_{(\text{D})}}{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}.\end{split} (38)

By putting Eqn. (13) into (A), we have

𝔼​‖D‖≤𝔼​‖I∑i=1I1(1−αt,i​(2−αt,i)​βt,i)2‖​≤(c)𝔼​‖I∑i=1I11−αt,i4​βt,i‖,𝔼delimited-∥∥D𝔼delimited-∥∥𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼1superscript1subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖2superscriptc𝔼delimited-∥∥𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼11superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖4subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\|\text{D}\|&\leq{\mathbb{E}}\left\|\frac{I}{{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{\frac{1}{{{{\left({1-{\alpha_{t,i}}(2-{\alpha_{t,i}})\sqrt{{\beta_{t,i}}}}\right)}^{2}}}}}}}\right\|{\mathop{\leq}\limits^{(\text{c})}}{\mathbb{E}}\left\|\frac{I}{{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}{\frac{1}{{1-{\alpha_{t,i}^{4}}\beta_{t,i}}}}}}\right\|,\end{split} (39)

where (c) always holds for αt,i∈[0,1]subscript𝛼𝑡𝑖01\alpha_{t,i}\in[0,1] and βt,i∈[0,1]subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖01\beta_{t,i}\in[0,1]. According to Definition 3, we have gt,i=αt,i4​βt,isubscript𝑔𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖4subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖g_{t,i}=\alpha_{t,i}^{4}\beta_{t,i} and gt=∑igt,i/Isubscript𝑔𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝑔𝑡𝑖𝐼g_{t}={\sum\nolimits_{i}{g_{t,i}}}/I. Since 1/(∑i11−gt,i)1subscript𝑖11subscript𝑔𝑡𝑖1/\big{(}{\sum\nolimits_{i}{\frac{1}{{{1-g_{t,i}}}}}}\big{)} is a concave function with respect to gt,isubscript𝑔𝑡𝑖g_{t,i}, based on Jensen’s inequality, we obtain

𝔼​‖A‖≤I∑i11−𝔼​(αt,i4​βt,i)=1−gt.𝔼delimited-∥∥A𝐼subscript𝑖11𝔼superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡𝑖4subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖1subscript𝑔𝑡\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\|\text{A}\|\leq{\frac{I}{{{\sum\nolimits_{i}{\frac{1}{{{1-{{\mathbb{E}}({\alpha_{t,i}^{4}\beta_{t,i}})}}}}}}}}}=1-g_{t}.\end{split} (40)

Since the training strategies of each device and the norm of the gradient of global data ‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖norm∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\| are independent, by putting Eqn. (40) back to Eqn. (38), we obtain

𝔼​‖Δt‖2≤𝔼​(ε​η2​(1−gt)​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2).𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝑡2𝔼𝜀superscript𝜂21subscript𝑔𝑡superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}{\left\|\Delta_{t}\right\|^{2}}&\leq{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}\varepsilon\eta^{2}{\big{(}1-g_{t}\big{)}}\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}\Big{)}.\end{split} (41)

Next, by putting Eqn. (41) back to Eqn. (37), we have

𝔼​(F​(𝒘t+1))≤𝔼​(F​(𝒘t)−1+ε​(gt−1)2​λ​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2).𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡1𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡1𝜀subscript𝑔𝑡12𝜆superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}})\big{)}&\leq{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-\frac{1+\varepsilon\big{(}g_{t}-1\big{)}}{2\lambda}{\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}}\Big{)}.\end{split} (42)

Subtracting F​(𝒘∗)𝐹superscript𝒘∗F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast}) in both sides of Eqn. (42) yields

𝔼(F(𝒘t+1−F(𝒘∗))≤𝔼​(F​(𝒘t)−1+ε​(gt−1)2​λ​‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2−F​(𝒘∗)).\displaystyle\small\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}&\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}}-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)}\\ &\leq{\mathbb{E}}\Big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-\frac{1+\varepsilon(g_{t}-1)}{2\lambda}{\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}}-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\Big{)}.\end{split} (43)

Based on Assumptions 2 and 3, we have [5, 45]

‖∇F​(𝒘t)‖2≥2​ν​(F​(𝒘t)−F​(𝒘∗)).superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡22𝜈𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡𝐹superscript𝒘∗\displaystyle\begin{split}\|\nabla F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})\|^{2}\geq 2\nu\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-F({{\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast}})\big{)}.\end{split} (44)

Plugging Eqn. (44) into Eqn. (43), we have

𝔼​(F​(𝒘t+1)−F​(𝒘∗))≤Zt​𝔼​(F​(𝒘t)−F​(𝒘∗)),𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡1𝐹superscript𝒘∗subscript𝑍𝑡𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑡𝐹superscript𝒘∗\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t+1}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)}&\leq Z_{t}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)},\end{split} (45)

where Zt=1−νλ​(1−ε​(1−gt))subscript𝑍𝑡1𝜈𝜆1𝜀1subscript𝑔𝑡Z_{t}=1-\frac{\nu}{\lambda}\left({1-{\varepsilon}({1-g_{t}})}\right).

Let gmin=min{gt}∀tsuperscript𝑔subscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡for-all𝑡g^{\min}=\mathop{\min}\{g_{t}\}_{\forall t} be the minimal global learning gain over T𝑇T global rounds. By recursively applying the above inequality from iteration round 0 to T𝑇T, we can obtain

𝔼​(F​(𝒘T)−F​(𝒘∗))≤ZT−1​𝔼​(F​(𝒘0)−F​(𝒘∗)),𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘𝑇𝐹superscript𝒘∗superscript𝑍𝑇1𝔼𝐹subscript𝒘0𝐹superscript𝒘∗\displaystyle\begin{split}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{T}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)}&\leq Z^{T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}F({{\boldsymbol{w}}_{0}})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\ast})\big{)},\end{split} (46)

where Z=1−νλ​(1−ε​(1−gmin))𝑍1𝜈𝜆1𝜀1superscript𝑔Z=1-\frac{\nu}{\lambda}\left({1-{\varepsilon}({1-g^{\min}})}\right). Thus, we complete the proof. ∎
